title: Trump’s Single Stroke of Brilliance
abstract: His initiative has been the key to much of his success, but lacking any sense of prudence, he does not understand the difference between a risk and a gamble.

title: U.S. Restores Legal Status for Many International Students, but Warns of Removals to Come
abstract: Immigration officials signaled that the Trump administration would continue to pursue efforts to terminate the legal status of the students, despite a wave of legal challenges.

title: George Santos’s Closing Act: A Prison Sentence of More Than 7 Years
abstract: Federal prosecutors had said Mr. Santos, whose pattern of lies and fraud led to his expulsion from Congress, should receive a lengthy sentence to “protect the public” from future fraud.

title: Voters See Trump’s Use of Power as Overreaching, Times/Siena Poll Finds
abstract: Skepticism has grown of his efforts to expand his authority and of his handling of issues long seen as strengths for him, including the economy and immigration.

title: Wisconsin Judge Arrested, Accused of Shielding Immigrant From Federal Agents
abstract: Judge Hannah Dugan was arrested on suspicion that she “intentionally misdirected federal agents away from” an immigrant being pursued by the authorities, the F.B.I. director said.

title: Four Perspectives on Trump’s Weak Poll Numbers
abstract: It’s not easy to burn this much good will so fast, and it doesn’t usually get any easier from here.

title: We Visited Rumeysa Ozturk in Detention. What We Saw Was a Warning to Us All.
abstract: The Constitution is only as strong as our willingness to defend it.

title: Another Gates Gets Wired In
abstract: Phoebe Gates, the youngest and most stylish of Bill and Melinda Gates’s children, steps into the spotlight as a founder of a new online shopping tool.

title: Kennedy Described My Daughter’s Reality
abstract: I don’t care if my child with autism ever pays taxes, but I do care that she may never have the opportunity to work or live independently.

title: Hegseth’s Personal Phone Use Created Vulnerabilities
abstract: The phone number used in the Signal chat could also be found in a variety of places, including on social media and a fantasy sports site.

title: ‘Vaguely Threatening’: Federal Prosecutor Queries Leading Medical Journal
abstract: The New England Journal of Medicine received a letter suggesting that it was biased and compromised by external pressure. Other journals have also received the letter.

title: Capital Burger, $3,000 in Cash and a D.H.S. Badge: A Washington Mystery
abstract: Kristi Noem, the top official charged with patrolling the nation’s borders and protecting it from terrorist threats, was burgled in plain view of her security detail.

title: Senior Russian Officer Killed in Car Explosion Near Moscow
abstract: The general’s death is the latest in a series of fatalities involving Ukraine’s opponents inside Russia. The authorities in Kyiv had no immediate comment.

title: Are You Getting Enough Protein? Let’s Find Out.
abstract: Try our interactive guide to the nutrient of the moment.

title: The Zuckerbergs Founded Two Bay Area Schools. Now They’re Closing.
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, opened the schools to help communities of color. Some families wonder if the shutting of the schools is related to his D.E.I. retrenchment.

title: Video Catches Nun Bidding Unique Farewell to Pope Francis, an Old Friend
abstract: Sister Geneviève Jeanningros left the queue of mourners and approached the body of Pope Francis as it lay in state.

title: What Elon Musk Didn’t Budget For: Firing Workers Costs Money, Too
abstract: An expert on the federal work force estimates that the speed and chaos of Mr. Musk’s cuts to the bureaucracy will cost taxpayers $135 billion this fiscal year.

title: Lawyer Is Charged With Sadistic Rapes of Women He Met Online
abstract: Ryan Hemphill was arraigned Thursday afternoon on a 116-count indictment. Authorities say he tortured, drugged and filmed women in his Midtown apartment.

title: As Recession Fears Rise, ‘No Buy’ Takes On New Urgency
abstract: The uncertainty surrounding President Trump’s tariffs has invigorated an underconsumption movement that took off early this year on TikTok and other platforms.

title: No More Food Dye in Froot Loops? Not So Fast.
abstract: Companies make packaged food without synthetic dyes in other countries. But despite pressure from Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the change isn’t likely to happen quickly in the United States.

abstract: The defense secretary sent sensitive information about strikes in Yemen to an encrypted group chat that included his wife and brother, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Larry David: My Dinner With Adolf
abstract: When a private meeting goes unexpectedly.

title: Trump Officials Blame Mistake for Setting Off Confrontation With Harvard
abstract: An official on the administration’s antisemitism task force told the university that a letter of demands had been sent without authorization.

abstract: The homeland security secretary was dining at a Washington, D.C., restaurant. She also lost her passport and keys.

abstract: The news program has faced mounting pressure from both President Trump and its corporate ownership at Paramount, the parent company of CBS News.

title: Francis, the First Latin American Pope, Dies at 88
abstract: After decades of conservative leadership, Francis tried to reset the course of the Roman Catholic Church, emphasizing inclusion and care for the marginalized over doctrinal purity.

abstract: Experts say there isn’t a single front-runner, but several names have been cited as indications of which direction the Roman Catholic Church might take.

title: The Trump Billionaires Who Run the Economy and the Things They Say
abstract: “You have to laugh to keep from crying,” one Republican pollster said about recent comments by the billionaires on the stock market, retirement funds and Social Security.

abstract: Baby bonuses and menstrual cycle classes are among the ideas pitched to Trump aides as they consider plans to try boosting the birthrate.

abstract: The plainclothes guards were involved in the forcible removal of a woman from a meeting hosted by local Republicans in Coeur d’Alene, prosecutors said.

abstract: The U.S. proposal would freeze territory along the current front lines of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which Ukraine has rejected.

title: An Immigrant Held in U.S. Custody ‘Simply Disappeared’
abstract: The Venezuelan man did not appear on a list of people sent to a prison in El Salvador, and his family and friends had no idea of his whereabouts.

abstract: Harvard’s lawsuit comes after the administration sought to force the university to comply with a list of demands by cutting billions in federal funding the school receives.

abstract: The defense secretary’s inner circle is in disarray, and distrust is growing among civil servants and senior military officials.

abstract: A group of transgender plaintiffs sued President Trump and the State Department over a new rule prohibiting passports from including a gender different from the sex listed on an original birth certificate.

abstract: Everything is under threat. What you care about can make it to the other side.

title: Trump Administration Draft Order Calls for Drastic Overhaul of State Department
abstract: The draft executive order would eliminate Africa operations and shut down bureaus working on democracy, human rights and refugee issues.

title: 17 Ways to Cut Your Risk of Stroke, Dementia and Depression All at Once
abstract: A new study identified overlapping factors that affect your odds of developing these brain diseases late in life.

title: Trump’s Approval Rating Has Been Falling Steadily, Polling Average Shows
abstract: President Trump’s approval rating has sunk to about 45 percent, down from 52 percent one week after he took office.

title: Val Kilmer, Film Star Who Played Batman and Jim Morrison, Dies at 65
abstract: A wide-ranging leading man who earned critical praise, he was known to be charismatic but unpredictable. At one point he dropped out of Hollywood for a decade.

title: Trump Administration Will Freeze $2 Billion After Harvard Refuses Demands
abstract: Federal officials said they would freeze the money after Harvard said it would not submit to requests to overhaul hiring and report international students who break rules.

abstract: The Signal group chat is only the latest in a string of self-inflicted wounds by the new administration.

abstract: Lisa Murkowski, a longtime senator from Alaska and an independent voice in an increasingly tribal party, has been the rare Republican on Capitol Hill willing to criticize President Trump’s actions.

title: 10 Small Things Neurologists Wish You’d Do for Your Brain
abstract: Easy everyday habits can help keep you sharp. And it’s never too late to start them.

abstract: This is the untold story of America’s hidden role in Ukrainian military operations against Russia’s invading armies.

abstract: The New Jersey senator spent much of his speech, which ended after more than 25 hours, assailing the Trump administration. He eclipsed Strom Thurmond’s filibuster of a civil rights bill in 1957.

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

abstract: Further studies are needed to determine whether K2-18b, which orbits a star 120 light-years away, is inhabited, or even habitable.

abstract: A man was charged with setting fire to the residence, forcing Gov. Josh Shapiro and his family to flee. Investigators said they found beer bottles with gasoline inside the house.

abstract: Firefighters found a 32-year-old man who weighed 68 pounds. The police say his stepmother locked him away when he was 12.

abstract: It will take a concerted effort by every sector of our society to respond to Trumpism’s threat.

abstract: A trial judge had ordered the Trump administration to take steps to return the migrant, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, from a notorious prison in El Salvador.

abstract: If you’re within five years of retiring, either before or after, you’re at your most vulnerable financially. Here are steps to weather the volatility.

abstract: With diagnoses at a record high, some experts have begun to question our assumptions about the condition — and how to treat it.

abstract: Demonstrators packed the streets in cities and towns to rail against government cutbacks, financial turmoil and what they viewed as attacks on democracy.

title: The Gen X Career Meltdown
abstract: Just when they should be at their peak, experienced workers in creative fields find that their skills are all but obsolete.

title: Catholics Expected a Revolution From Francis, Just Not the One He Gave Them
abstract: Liberals hoped he’d ordain women or allow gay marriage. Conservatives thought he’d tear up Church doctrine. But his papacy favored debate over radical action.

title: Five Takeaways From the Times/Siena Poll
abstract: Voters think President Trump has gone too far in wielding his power. They see the start of his term as “scary” and “chaotic.” And while it’s still early, they disapprove of his handling of many issues.

title: 2-Year-Old U.S. Citizen Deported ‘With No Meaningful Process,’ Judge Suspects
abstract: A federal judge in Louisiana said the deportation of the child to Honduras with her mother, even though her father had filed an emergency petition, appeared to be “illegal and unconstitutional.”

abstract: The pardon of Paul Walczak, who had been convicted of tax crimes, comes as the president uses clemency to reward allies and swipe at perceived enemies.

abstract: Officials in Kyiv plan to deliver their proposal to President Trump’s team, after rejecting a White House plan that would have given the Kremlin much of what it wants.

abstract: Plans for a third round of talks in three weeks have raised hopes for an Iran nuclear accord, which could avert a new Mideast conflict. President Trump said he believed a deal was within reach.

abstract: The risk of exposing a military still being modernized may constrain Prime Minister Narendra Modi as he weighs retaliation for a terrorist attack.

abstract: She accused Jeffrey Epstein and his co-conspirator, Ghislaine Maxwell, of recruiting her to join their predatory ring and sued Prince Andrew for sexual assault.

abstract: The authorities said a man used a chain saw to destroy more than a dozen trees in downtown Los Angeles, an attack that saddened and rattled residents and city leaders.

abstract: The judge warned Attorney General Pam Bondi to temper her statements about Luigi Mangione to ensure a fair trial on charges of killing a health insurance executive.

abstract: President Donald Trump is weighing in on a school mascot dispute at Massapequa High School, where some parents are upset that a Chiefs mascot and logo must go under a state rule.

abstract: Faced with shortages and rising prices for domestic rice, many Japanese are doing what was once unthinkable — buying a foreign variety.

abstract: Sampling the outpouring of reader responses to the comedian’s imaginary dinner with Hitler. Also: The law firms’ test; a plea for democracy.

abstract: The Times Opinion columnist discusses religion and belief — at this moment in our politics and in our lives more generally.

abstract: Assenting to Russia’s annexation of Crimea would have global consequences.

abstract: DeSantis walked so that Trump could run.

abstract: And what happens when your country becomes a place people no longer want to come to.

title: Can the Catholic Church Quit the Culture Wars?
abstract: The challenges for Catholicism in the modern world.

abstract: As more vigorous law enforcement has reduced crime, progressives are still trying to eliminate tools that have made the police more effective.

abstract: The operation in Yemen has sent the Trump administration into an exorbitant, potentially escalatory spiral.

title: The World Seems to Be Surrendering to Climate Change
abstract: The state of the climate future, Part I.

title: How I Describe Myself Politically These Days
abstract: America needs to figure out how to dominate the industries of the future. Call me a “Waymo Democrat.”

title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

title: David Paton, Creator of Flying Eye Hospital, Dies at 94
abstract: An idealistic ophthalmologist, he came up with an ingenious way to treat blindness in far-flung places: by outfitting an airplane with an operating room.

title: The Trump Administration Wants Seafloor Mining. What Does That Mean?
abstract: A recent executive order would accelerate mining in little-understood undersea ecosystems.

title: F.D.A. Scientists Are Reinstated at Agency Food Safety Labs
abstract: After 20 percent of the agency’s work force was cut, federal health officials have decided to bring back some experts and review firings to fill gaps in critical roles.

title: Trump budget draft ends Narcan program and other addiction measures.
abstract: A $56 million grant to train emergency responders and supply them with the overdose reversal spray, plus other programs that address addiction, could be eliminated.

abstract: A new executive order pits the United States against the rest of the world over the question of who can exploit mineral resources in shared waters.

abstract: The decades-long research effort has contributed to thousands of research papers, altering medical care for women around the world.

title: Trump Cuts Threaten Agency Running Meals on Wheels
abstract: A tiny division responsible for overseeing services for people with disabilities and older Americans is being dismantled as part of an overhaul by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary.

title: Leaders of Mental Health Giant Promised Big Bonuses to Deal With Federal Investigations
abstract: Acadia Healthcare’s chief executive was awarded a $1.8 million bonus to respond to “unprecedented governmental inquiries” into allegations of holding psychiatric patients against their will.

title: A Planned E.U. Rule Has Coffee Growers in Ethiopia Scrambling
abstract: The measure will require geolocation data to show that beans aren’t linked to deforestation. Farmers say they need more time to prepare.

title: New Study Could Bolster Climate Laws to Make Polluters Pay
abstract: Vermont was the first state to try to hold polluters accountable for climate disasters. New research aims to assign specific responsibility.

abstract: The few domestic companies that still make protective gear for health care workers have clamored for federal intervention. But they worry President Trump’s trade war with China won’t help.

abstract: Two major proposals led by Jared Kushner and a new airport championed by the Albanian government focus on an area prized for its biodiversity. Are they a sign of things to come?

abstract: Stranded astronauts and celebrity space tourism have piqued interest in space — and a photography exhibition in the museum is making the most of it.

title: Almost Half of Americans Breathe Unhealthy Air, Report Finds
abstract: Weakening or rolling back longstanding environmental regulations would worsen the problem, the American Lung Association assessment says.

abstract: Despite a 1 percent increase in 2024, U.S. birthrates remained in a historic slump, a trend that worries demographers and cultural critics.

title: Measles Surge in Southwest Is Now the Largest Single Outbreak Since 2000
abstract: Growing case numbers suggest that the national total will surpass that seen during the last large outbreak in 2019.

abstract: A growing understanding of how “reproductive” hormones sculpt the brain could transform the management of neurological conditions.

abstract: Timberline Knolls, a mental health center owned by Acadia Healthcare, skimped on staff. Then came a series of tragedies.

abstract: Nine states have set goals to conserve 30 percent of their land by 2030. Maryland got there first.

abstract: A cluster of evangelical groups in the state is pushing for environmental action. Leaders say they’re following the biblical mandate to care for creation.

title: How a Funeral Director Brought Wind Power to Rural Missouri
abstract: Every year for nearly two decades, the small city of Rock Port has been producing more electricity from wind energy than it needs.

abstract: Simple, affordable initiatives like rain gardens are helping to soak up water in New Orleans.

title: Herbert J. Gans, 97, Dies; Upended Myths of Urban and Suburban Life
abstract: A leading sociologist, he explored American society up close — living in a Levittown at one point — to gain insight into issues of race, class, the media and even the Yankees.

title: E.P.A. Set to Cancel Grants Aimed at Protecting Children From Toxic Chemicals
abstract: The cancellations, set to apply to pending and active grants, also affect research into “forever chemicals” contaminating the food supply.
